entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French salvage, savage, from Late Latin salvaticus, alteration of Latin silvaticus of the woods, wild, from silva wood, forest

def.dt: :not domesticated or under human control :untamed savage beasts
:lacking the restraints normal to civilized human beings :fierce ferocious a savage criminal
:wild uncultivated seldom have I seen such savage scenery Douglas Carruthers
:boorish rude the savage bad manners of most motorists M. P. O'Connor
:lacking complex or advanced culture :uncivilized a savage country
:a person belonging to a primitive society
Michael Joseph 1872–1940 prime min. of New Zealand (1935–40)
:a mythic conception of people belonging to non-European cultures as having innate natural simplicity and virtue uncorrupted by European civilization
